title: Effects of different wall‐breaking methods on the nutrient release of Ganoderma lucidum spore powder in vitro digestion
content:
Abstract

Background

The hard double-walled structure of Ganoderma lucidum spore powder (GLSP) is difficult for the human body to be digested, so it is very important to break the wall of GLSP.

Results

In this study, the wall of GLSP was broken by mechanical milling at room temperature (MM-R) and ultra-fine grinding at low temperature (UFG-L), respectively. Compared with MM-R, UFG-L can better retain the sporangium powder's morphological and structural integrity. During the in vitro digestion, compared with unbroken GLSP, the release amounts of polysaccharides and triterpenes from broken GLSP were significantly increased, and the release amounts increased with the increase of specific surface area. The bioaccessibility of polysaccharide and triterpene from unbroken GLSP after the intestinal stage were 29.52% and 5.37%, respectively. The bioaccessibility of polysaccharides and triterpene from broken GLSP by MM-R after the intestinal phase were 39.73%–72.45% and 16.44%–24.97%, while those by UFG-L were 44.53%–104.18% and 12.96%–32.90%, respectively.

Conclusion

In conclusion, the active ingredients of broken GLSP showed better digestion and absorption abilities than unbroken GLSP. Moreover, the specific surface area of GLSP by UFG-L was lower than that of MM-R, and the bioaccessibility of GLSP by UFG-L was higher than that of MM-R.
